Definition.WordDefinition: PLATITUDE, n. The fundamental element and special glory of popular literature. A thought that snores in words that smoke. The wisdom of a million fools in the diction of a dullard. A fossil sentiment in artificial rock. A moral without the fable. All that is mortal of a departed truth. A demi-tasse of milk-and-mortality. The Pope's-nose of a featherless peacock. A jelly-fish withering on the shore of the sea of thought. The cackle surviving the egg. A desiccated epigram.

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Platitude \Plat"i*tude\, n. [F., from plat flat. See {Plate}.] 1. The quality or state of being flat, thin, or insipid; flat commonness; triteness; staleness of ideas of language. [1913 Webster]
To hammer one golden grain of wit into a sheet of infinite platitude. --Motley. [1913 Webster]
2. A thought or remark which is flat, dull, trite, or weak; a truism; a commonplace. [1913 Webster]
platitude n : a trite or obvious remark [syn: {cliche}, {banality}, {commonplace}, {bromide}]
